Query1.title: Parmesan cheese is not what it seems - The Washington Post
Query1.snippet: Feb 17, 2016 ... Nowhere in the definition is there the suggestion that "wood pulp" would be an appropriate ingredient. Nor does it say it's acceptable to ...

content.content:
In the 1950s, the Food and Drug Administration established an official definition for parmesan cheese. , it cannot contain more than 32 precent moisture, while it must have a "granular texture," come with a "hard and brittle rind," grate "readily," and be made from cow's milk, among others things.
Nowhere in the definition is there the suggestion that "wood pulp" would be an appropriate ingredient. Nor does it say it's acceptable to substitute in less expensive cheeses, such as cheddar, swiss, and mozzarella. That's not surprising: It should go without saying parmesan cheese should be parmesan cheese.
And yet, somehow, parmesan cheese advertised as 100 percent parmesan appears to be including wood pulp and other cheese, unbeknownst to us.
The unusual tactic was first flagged by the FDA in 2012, when it found evidence that Castle Cheese Inc, which sold a variety of shaved parmesan and romano cheeses, was introducing unexpected substances into its parmesan cheese products. The government agency wrote the company , which was filled with unambiguous language like "your product labels declare that the products are parmesan cheese or romano cheese, but they are in fact a mixture of trimmings of various cheeses and other ingredients" and "your parmesan cheese products do not contain any parmesan cheese."
What distinguishes one cheese from another is a consequence of both its ingredients and the process in which its made. In the United States,...[Content truncated]

It covers a wide range of topics, including food industry controversies and health-related issues. Its editorial standards and history of journalistic integrity contribute to its high score, making it a reliable source for detecting fake news.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This source discusses the FDA's formal definition of Parmesan cheese, clarifying that wood pulp is not allowed. It connects the legislation to the mislabeling cases, providing a critical perspective on what genuine Parmesan should consist of. This is highly relevant in determining the veracity of the claim.

content.content:
[Content truncated]... With Wood Pulp in Cheese
=========================================
Separating the curds from the wood
by  Updated Jan 23, 2017, 4:19pm EST
Share this story
----------------
*   
*   
*   
### **Share** All sharing options for: The Real Problem With Wood Pulp in Cheese
*   
*   
*   
  !/cdn.vox-cdn.com/uploads/chorus_image/image/48990631/4333573403_2fd304cdea_b.0.0.jpg)
> **UPDATE, January 23:** Last week,  Universal Cheese & Drying and International Packing, the company behind the Castle Cheese brand, with a $500,000 fine for their roles in the mislabeling. , former Cheese Castle executive Michelle Myrter received a sentence of three years probation and a $5,000 fine after pleading guilty to food adulteration. She was facing a  of as much as three years in prison.
When it comes to the food industry, it's not always easy being cheesy. That's the takeaway from  detailing the use of cellulose (aka wood pulp) in shredded cheese products in the U.S. The use of fillers like cellulose is hotly contested, but perhaps not for the reason you might think.
An FDA investigation found that a Pennsylvania company, Castle Cheese Inc., had doctored its so-called "Parmesan" with a mix of cheap cheddar cheese and cellulose (also known as wood pulp). The President of the company is currently facing a hefty fine and prison time for  the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act.
It's really a kind of consumer fraud.
While much of the media's focus has been on the wood pulp, cellulose is in fact a very common food additive. The legality has more to do with the fact that the cheese is improperly labeled: The FDA's  regarding Parmesan requires that each ingredient be listed on the label (with the exception of animal, plant or microbial enzymes, which can simply be declared "enzymes").
Nora Weiser, executive director of the American Cheese Society, says cellulose isn't found in wheels of cheese, but in shredded varieties, where it's used as an anti-caking agent. "It is a legal, food-grade additive," she says. "It keeps the grated cheese products from clumping."
According to Jaydee Hanson, Policy Director at the Center for Food Safety, the FDA allows cheese products to contain up to four percent cellulose. Any more than that might skirt the law, but Hanson says it's likely not all that harmful. "You...[Content truncated]

It discusses the legal implications of using such fillers and highlights consumer fraud issues, clearly tying back to the claim about wood pulp being present in Parmesan cheese products. This is highly relevant to understanding the truthfulness of the claim.

Query1.title: Is there really wood pulp and sawdust in your Parmesan cheese ...
Query1.snippet: Now, you're probably thinking this is incredibly deceptive or possibly a straight up lie. But with food law, the difference of one word, in this case 'grated,' ...

content.content:
[Content truncated]...ings, and deceptive tactics that I always feel inclined to investigate.
And I found it hard to believe that chunks of wood were being tossed into cheese all willy nilly. There’s too many laws and regulations for that to fly.
But there is some truth behind these reports and several cheese companies including Kraft Heinz, Walmart, Jewel-Osco owner Albertsons, SuperValu and the manufacturer Icco Cheese have been involved in a lawsuit over their 100% grated Parmesan cheese.
Because guess what — it’s not 100% Parmesan cheese.
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
    *   
    *   
### So, is there wood pulp in my cheese?
!
The short answer is — no. This is one of those exaggerations.
But, there is a reason for the lawsuits. The fight is over a food-safe additive called cellulose.
Now, you might be thinking there’s no cellulose in my Parmesan cheese, but if you flip over the container you’ll see cellulose on nearly every ingredient list for grated or shredded Parmesan cheese.
It doesn’t matter if the container says ‘100% grated Parmesan cheese’ it still contains cellulose. It’s not 100% cheese.
Now, you’re probably thinking this is incredibly deceptive or possibly a straight up lie.
But with food law, the difference of one word, in this case ‘grated,’ can have huge implications.
Another example is the difference between a label stating ‘chocolate’ versus ‘chocolatey.’ The former is real chocolate while the later is a mimic of chocolate called compound coating.
### Then, what does ‘100% grated Parmesan cheese’ mean?
The key word in this claim is ‘grated.’ If a product says ‘100% cheese’ it contains only cheese, but if you throw in the word ‘grated’ it has a whole new definition according to the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR).
In the food industry, the CFR is essentially the bible. It’s the book that defines what certain foods are and what ingredients can be included. And according to the CFR a  can include the following _optional_ ingredients:
*   Antimycotics
*   Anticaking agents
*   Spices
*   Flavorings
So, legally the claim of ‘100% grated cheese’ is correct, even if an anti-caking agent like cellulose is used. However, to most people this would be seen as pretty misleading...[Content truncated]

While it has useful content, it’s more focused on personal blogging and may lack the rigorous journalistic fact-checking associated with higher credibility sites. Its factual accuracy may vary depending on individual articles, but it provides some degree of insight into food topics, including controversies.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence confirms that there is a legal distinction concerning the use of cellulose (wood pulp) in grated cheeses. It explicitly states that cellulose can be found in nearly all grated or shredded Parmesan cheese despite misleading labels claiming they are '100% Parmesan cheese'. This closely relates to the claim as it directly addresses the use of wood pulp in Parmesan cheese production, providing specifics about legal definitions concerning food labeling.

Query2.title: The Amount of Wood Pulp in Grated Parmesan Cheese May ...
Query2.snippet: Jun 22, 2017 ... ... contain cellulose, an anti-clumping agent made from wood ... All the brands but Kraft told Bloomberg they were investigating the matter.

content.content:
[Content truncated]... grated Parmesan should have wood? It sounds like a silly nursery rhyme, but let's take it as a serious question for a moment because, , not only is grated Parmesan cheese allowed to contain cellulose, an anti-clumping agent made from wood pulp, but the percentage of cellulose in some products may surprise you.
In light of recent court proceedings where a Pennsylvania cheesemaker is expected to plead guilty to selling "100 percent grated Parmesan" that was actually made entirely from cheaper Swiss, mozzarella and white cheddar cheese, as well as cellulose filler, Bloomberg Business decided to dig into the scandalous world of grated cheese.
Neil Schuman of Arthur Schuman Inc, America's largest hard Italian cheese seller, told Bloomberg he believes that 20 percent of the grated parmesan on the market is mislabeled. "The tipping point was grated cheese, where less than 40 percent of the product was actually a cheese product," he said. "Consumers are innocent, and they're not getting what they bargained for. And that's just wrong."
Of course, clumpy grated parmesan isn't awesome either, so some cellulose is allowed and acceptable when in the 2 to 4 percent range, according to one cheese expert. But Bloomberg decided to test a few brands to see where they fall, and though they didn't turn up any chunks of discarded Ikea furniture, many failed to land in that range.
Based on their results, Essential Everyday 100% Grated Parmesan Cheese from Jewel-Osco landed at 8.8 percent cellulose. Great Value 100% Grated Parmesan Cheese from Walmart clocked in at 7.8 percent. Even Whole Foods, despite not listing cellulose as an ingredient, had 0.3 percent of the filler. And the extremely common Kraft had 3.8 percent cellulose.
All the brands but Kraft told Bloomberg they were investigating the matter. Kraft, meanwhile, said they were "committed to the quality of our products." It's worth noting that the FDA could step in on these matters, but in general, they prioritize health risks over woody cheese.
So though the old adage is "read the label," for consumers, that might not do much. The best bet is probably to buy actual parmesan cheese and grate it yourself. Then you can add as much wood as you'd like.
\\]

content.content:
[Content truncated]... than **8 years old**
So your store-bought parmesan cheese is made with wood pulp. Is that so bad?
============================================================================
This article is more than 8 years old
News that the FDA has found non-dairy filler ingredients used to make paper in your parmesan cheese isn’t great, but will it kill you? Probably not
Wed 17 Feb 2016 12.18 ESTLast modified on Sat 18 Aug 2018 10.00 EDT
The grocery store parmesan cheese in the green-topped plastic container you shake over pasta dishes contains non-dairy filler ingredients like wood pulp, according to a  from Bloomberg.
In 2012, the US Food and Drug Administration investigated the Pennsylvania cheese factory Castle  Inc and found the company was doctoring its “100% real parmesan” with filler ingredients like wood pulp, or cheaper cheeses like cheddar, swiss and mozzarella.
Following the FDA’s findings, Bloomberg investigated other store-bought grated parmesan and discovered high percentages of cellulose – essentially powdered wood pulp and the main ingredient in paper – in four different brands.
Bloomberg found that “Essential Everyday 100% Grated Parmesan Cheese, from Jewel-Osco, was 8.8% cellulose, while Wal-Mart Stores Inc.’s Great Value 100% Grated Parmesan Cheese registered 7.8%, according to test results. Whole Foods 365 brand didn’t list cellulose as an ingredient on the label, but still tested at 0.3%. Kraft had 3.8%.”
Dean Sommer, a cheese technologist at the Center for Dairy Research in Madison, Wisconsin, told Bloomberg that cellulose is a safe additive and an acceptable level is 2% to 4%.
Amy Bentley, a professor in the department of nutrition at New York University, said cellulose is not necessarily dangerous, and could possibly be healthy. Cellulose is considered to be a fiber and appears in some laxative products and drinks, she said. Bentley compared the grated parmesan to cheese products like Velveeta – not pure cheese, but still safe to consume.
“It could possibly be healthy, but people don’t usually think that grated cheese is where their source of fiber is coming from,” Bentley said. “Could it be toxic? I don’t think so.”
However, just because cellulose figures prominently in grated parmesan, people shouldn’t turn to it as a source for fiber intake, she said. “It’s cheese, it’s not Metamuc...[Content truncated]

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence reports on lab tests revealing that many store-bought parmesan cheeses contain cellulose, highlighting its presence as a filler. It closely correlates with the question about wood pulp's role in parmesan, supporting the claim effectively.

content.content:
### A food scientist explains the origins of these headlines
!
A handful of cheese companies have found themselves the subject of some pretty salacious headlines like  and the .
As a food scientist, this type of flashy news always catches my eye. I’ve seen so many exaggerations, misunderstandings, and deceptive tactics that I always feel inclined to investigate.
And I found it hard to believe that chunks of wood were being tossed into cheese all willy nilly. There’s too many laws and regulations for that to fly.
But there is some truth behind these reports and several cheese companies including Kraft Heinz, Walmart, Jewel-Osco owner Albertsons, SuperValu and the manufacturer Icco Cheese have been involved in a lawsuit over their 100% grated Parmesan cheese.
Because guess what — it’s not 100% Parmesan cheese.
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
    *   
    *   
### So, is there wood pulp in my cheese?
!
The short answer is — no. This is one of those exaggerations.
But, there is a reason for the lawsuits. The fight is over a food-safe additive called cellulose.
Now, you might be thinking there’s no cellulose in my Parmesan cheese, but if you flip over the container you’ll see cellulose on nearly every ingredient list for grated or shredded Parmesan cheese.
It doesn’t matter if the container says ‘100% grated Parmesan cheese’ it still contains cellulose. It’s not 100% cheese.
Now, you’re probably thinking this is incredibly deceptive or possibly a straight up lie.
But with food law, the difference of one word, in this case ‘grated...[Content truncated]

While it provides useful information, it may not always adhere to stringent journalistic standards seen in more established news outlets. This website primarily focuses on food-related content, and though it is credible, it may lack the rigorous fact-checking and editorial oversight of larger publications.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence explicitly states that while there are regulations, certain cheese companies have been implicated in lawsuits for using cellulose (wood pulp) in their parmesan products, challenging the notion that these products are 100% parmesan. This strongly supports the claim that wood pulp is used in parmesan cheese.

[Content truncated]... grated Parmesan should have wood? It sounds like a silly nursery rhyme, but let's take it as a serious question for a moment because, , not only is grated Parmesan cheese allowed to contain cellulose, an anti-clumping agent made from wood pulp, but the percentage of cellulose in some products may surprise you.
In light of recent court proceedings where a Pennsylvania cheesemaker is expected to plead guilty to selling "100 percent grated Parmesan" that was actually made entirely from cheaper Swiss, mozzarella and white cheddar cheese, as well as cellulose filler, Bloomberg Business decided to dig into the scandalous world of grated cheese.
Neil Schuman of Arthur Schuman Inc, America's largest hard Italian cheese seller, told Bloomberg he believes that 20 percent of the grated parmesan on the market is mislabeled. "The tipping point was grated cheese, where less than 40 percent of the product was actually a cheese product," he said. "Consumers are innocent, and they're not getting what they bargained for. And that's just wrong."
Of course, clumpy grated parmesan isn't awesome either, so some cellulose is allowed and acceptable when in the 2 to 4 percent range, according to one cheese expert. But Bloomberg decided to test a few brands to see where they fall, and though they didn't turn up any chunks of discarded Ikea furniture, many failed to land in that range.
Based on their results, Essential Everyday 100% Grated Parmesan Cheese from Jewel-Osco landed at 8.8 percent cellulose. Great Value 100% Grated Parmesan Cheese from Walmart clocked in at 7.8 percent. Even Whole Foods, despite not listing cellulose as an ingredient, had 0.3 percent of the filler. And the extremely common Kraft had 3.8 percent cellulose.
All the brands but Kraft told Bloomberg they were investigating the matter. Kraft, meanwhile, said they were "committed to the quality of our products." It's worth noting that the FDA could step in on these matters, but in general, they prioritize health risks over woody cheese.
So though the old adage is "read the label," for consumers, that might not do much. The best bet is probably to buy actual parmesan cheese and grate it yourself. Then you can add as much wood as you'd like.

QA.Question: Is it true that wood pulp is used in the production of certain parmesan cheeses?
QA.Answer: Yes, it is true that wood pulp is used in the production of certain Parmesan cheeses, specifically in some shredded cheese products. This wood pulp is commonly known as cellulose, which serves as an anti-caking agent to prevent clumping in grated cheeses. The FDA allows cheese products to contain up to 4% cellulose, and it is typically not harmful in those amounts. However, the controversy arises from cases where some brands have misrepresented their products as '100% Parmesan' while including significant amounts of cellulose, wood pulp, or other cheaper cheese types. A notable incident involved Castle Cheese Inc., which was found by the FDA to have doctored its Parmesan products with a mix of cheaper cheddar and cellulose, leading to legal repercussions for the company. Research has indicated that a considerable portion of grated Parmesan on the market may not contain authentic Parmesan cheese at all. One estimate suggests that around 20% of grated Parmesan could be mislabeled, with some containing over 8% cellulose, which exceeds the FDA's recommended limit. Thus, while cellulose (wood pulp) is an approved additive and can be legally present in small amounts in shredded cheese, many products labeled as Parmesan do not adhere to the standards that define true Parmesan cheese, leading to both consumer fraud and health considerations.
